text: Family Member: Do they die or are they just inhibited? Doctor: Yeah they like ninety nine percent die then maybe not one hundred precent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So that’s with the injection. Then there’s a little cylinder, a little flexible cylinder about this long – Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: - that can be implanted under the skin. Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time?

text: Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_, Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if

text: Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___? Doctor: I went to ____ in M___. Patient: Okay, I see the gold and blue socks. Doctor: Oh no, I had an orange shirt on, so I put on orange socks. Patient: Okay, a maze of blue. Patient: Bless you! Doctor: Now the first-in-human study, I don’t think you’re eligible for it because of the liver. They only want bone disease. Uh- A lot of paperwork you’ve got read. Patient: Yeah, I hear that. Doctor: You can check with Dr. G___ Any notes from us - So let’s get a hold of your results from your most recent lung scan and your visit from pulmonology as to what they say or their thinking is behind your gasping spells. It’s important. Ah, your ARV7 is positive. That suggests that the Enzalutamide may not work very long. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s likely in the near future that you’ll need new belly scan, abdominal scan, bone scan for us to more directly determine that the Enzalutamide is not benefiting you. So we tried to get your tissue sent for molecular testing but when we sent it, it wasn’t adequate for that sort of evaluation, so Dr. G__ may look at other options. Sometimes they can do another biopsy or do a blood test, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: but that’s not as good, but it’s something that’s easy, though. So once we’ve determined that your cancer has continued to grow, the standard therapy would be to move you to chemotherapy and if the name docetaxel based chemotherapy. Alternatively we’ve got two studies. I got rid of one as I wrote that.

text: Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do? Doctor: Yeah, so that; we have talked about that. You know your kidney function has gotten better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know so that is one of the key parts about you being eligible, that if your kidney function was too high, makes it difficult for us to use chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Chemotherapy with your numbers today, you could certainly go ahead and start moving forward with that and picking a date. You know for you to do the clinical trial then we do have to have you; D___ even kept an eye on you and let me know that you were in the hospital. You know we’ve got all kinds of I think Dr._____ one note said that Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
